start.title:
Inbox Under Siege

Battling Spam with Probability
start.description: Can you help Ethan and Alicia build a smart spam filter to sort out real customer emails from junk? In this STEAMQuest, you'll use two-way tables, conditional probability, independence, and classification thresholds to make data-driven decisions and improve SprintTech's inbox!

S2_D1_F3_C0.heading: Welcome to SprintTech!
S2_D1_F3_C0.body: I'm Alicia, and today I'll be working with our Junior Developer, Ethan, to solve an important problem. SprintTech is a marketing agency where emails are essential for reaching customers. With so many emails coming in every day, it's challenging to separate the real customer email from the spam. By using probability and data analysis, we'll build a spam filter that keeps inboxes organized and efficient!

S3.S3_D1_F6_C1: Ethan, our inbox is overflowing with spam emails! It's hard to find real customer emails.
S3.S3_D2_F7_C2: That sounds frustrating. We need to filter the emails!
S3.S3_D3_F8_C1: Let's build a filter to classify them into spam and not spam automatically.
S3.S3_D4_F9_C2: How would that even work? Spam looks different every time.
S3.S3_D5_F10_C1: We can analyze past emails to find patterns and use probability to decide which ones are likely spam.
S3.S3_D6_F11_C2: Interesting! If this helps us save time and catch real emails faster, I'm ready.

S4.S4_D1_F12_C2: Okay, so where do we start?
S4.S4_D2_F13_C1: First, we need to look at past emails and identify common spam features‚Äîlike certain words, links, or unknown senders.
S4.S4_D3_F14_C2: Makes sense. If we can find patterns, we can use them to predict which emails are spam.
S4.S4_D4_F15_C1: Exactly! Let's go through some sample emails and track their features.

about.heading: Understanding the Math Behind Spam Detection
about.body:
This interactive helps track how often certain features (like the word "FREE" or multiple links) appear in spam vs. non-spam emails. The collected data is organized in a two-way frequency table, which allows us to calculate conditional probabilities and analyze patterns in spam detection.

Two-Way Frequency Table

A two-way table organizes data into two categories:

  • Rows: Email classification (Spam or Not Spam)
  • Columns: Feature presence (Feature Present or Feature Absent)

Each cell in the table represents the count of emails that match both conditions.

help.heading: Calculating probability of words appearing in spam emails
help.body:
1. ‚Ä¢
    Enter the probabilities of email having word 'FREE' known that it's spam (P(FREE | spam)) and an email having word 'WIN' known that it's spam (P(WIN | spam)).
  2. ‚Ä¢
    The probability of email having both words 'FREE' and 'WIN' known that it's spam (P(FREE and WIN | spam)) is displayed on the screen.
  3. ‚Ä¢
    Also if we assume that both features are independent, then the probability can be calculated easily using below formula: P(FREE and WIN | spam) = P(FREE | spam) P(WIN | spam)

about.heading: Conditional Probability Formula
about.body:
Conditional probability measures the likelihood of an event occurring given that another event has already happened. The formula is:

P(A | B) = P(A and B) / P(B)

P(A | B) = Probability of event A occurring given that B has occurred

P(A and B) = Probability of both A and B occurring together

P(B) = Probability of event B occurring

For example, the probability that an email contains the word "FREE" given that it is spam is:

P(FREE | spam) = P(FREE and spam) / P(spam)

Checking for Feature Independence

If two features (e.g., "FREE" and "WIN") are independent, then the probability of both appearing in a spam email should equal the product of their individual probabilities:

P(FREE and WIN | spam) = P(FREE | spam) √ó P(WIN | spam)

If this equation holds, the features are independent; otherwise, they are dependent, meaning knowing one feature helps predict the other.

S7.S7_D1_F34_C1: Let's use this interactive tool to test whether features 'FREE' and 'WIN' are independent or not.
S7.S7_D2_F35_C1: Enter the probabilities in the input boxes. The probability of 'FREE' appearing in an email, given that it is spam, is 0.95, and the probability of 'WIN' appearing in an email, given that it is spam, is 0.80.
S7.S7_D3_F36_C1: What is the probability that both 'FREE' and 'WIN' are present in an email known that it's spam?
S7.S7_D4_F37_C2: How can we check whether both features 'FREE' and 'WIN' are independent or not?
S7.S7_D5_F38_C1:
We will check whether the probability that both 'FREE' and 'WIN' are present in a spam email is equal to the product of the probability of 'FREE' present in a spam email and the probability of 'WIN' present in a spam email.
P(FREE and WIN | spam) = P(FREE | spam) √ó P(WIN | spam)
S7.S7_D7_F40_C1: That means they're independent and checking for both together doesn't give us extra predictive power, each feature alone tells us the same thing.

S8.S8_D1_F42_C1: Alright, we confirmed that some features are useful for predicting spam. Ethan, can you please write a code to calculate the spam probability of each email?
S8.S8_D2_F43_C2: Yes, sure! But how will we decide whether the email is spam or not?
S8.S8_D3_F44_C1: We need a threshold: if spam probability is above it, we mark it as spam, if below it, we keep it in the inbox.
S8.S8_D4_F45_C2: I've written code to calculate the spam probability of an email.
S8.S8_D5_F46_C1: Excellent! Now let's calculate the probability for each email and try filtering emails with different threshold values.

about.heading: Understanding the Math Behind Threshold Adjustment
about.body:
A threshold is a cutoff value used to classify emails as spam or not spam based on their probability score. In this interactive, adjusting the threshold changes how emails are filtered.

How the Threshold Works

  • ‚Ä¢
    If an email's spam probability is above the threshold, it is classified as spam.
  • ‚Ä¢
    If an email's spam probability is below the threshold, it is classified as not spam.

The goal is to balance false positives and false negatives to create an effective filter.

Key Probability Concepts

  1. 1.
    False Positive (Type I Error): A real email is incorrectly classified as spam.
  2. 2.
    False Negative (Type II Error): A spam email is incorrectly classified as not spam.
  3. 3.
    Trade-Off in Classification:
    • ‚Ä¢
      Lower threshold ‚Üí More emails marked as spam (reduces false negatives but increases false positives).
    • ‚Ä¢
      Higher threshold ‚Üí Fewer emails marked as spam (reduces false positives but increases false negatives).

S9.S9_D1E_FX_C1: Look at this, an actual customer got flagged as spam!
S9.S9_D2_F49_C2: Yeah, that 'Free trial of product integration' email has a 55% spam probability, but it's a real inquiry.
S9.S9_D3_F50_C1: That's a false positive, we're blocking something we shouldn't. Increase the threshold to 70% so only emails with stronger spam signals get flagged.
S9.S9_D4_F51_C2: Looks better! The customer email is back in the inbox, but we still caught obvious spam like 'CLAIM YOUR FREE PRIZE NOW!!!'
S9.S9_D5_F52_C1: This proves that setting the right threshold is all about balance, we need to reduce false positives while still catching real spam.

S10.S10_D1_F54_C1: We've adjusted the threshold to reduce false positives, but we need to see the bigger picture, how much is this costing us?
S10.S10_D2_F55_C2: Right. If we block a real customer email, we might lose our customers. If we let spam through, it wastes time. Each mistake has a cost.
S10.S10_D3_F56_C1: Exactly! That's why we need to calculate how much it costs for our current threshold.
S10.S10_D4_F57_C2: Do we've any tool or calculator to calculate how much it costs?

about.heading: Understanding the Cost of Classification Errors
about.body:
Spam filters make decisions based on probability, but misclassifications come with costs. This interactive helps analyze the financial impact of false positives (blocking real emails) and false negatives (allowing spam).

Key Concepts in Cost Analysis

  1. 1.
    False Positive Cost: When a real email is mistakenly flagged as spam, it can result in lost business or missed opportunities.
    False Positive Cost = Number of missed Real Emails √ó Cost per missed Real Email
  2. 2.
    False Negative Cost: When a spam email is mistakenly allowed in the inbox, it can waste employee time or introduce security risks.
    False Negative Cost = Number of missed Spam Emails √ó Cost per missed Spam Email
  3. 3.
    Total Cost: The overall financial impact combines both types of errors:
    Total Cost = False Positive Cost + False Negative Cost

Adjusting the Threshold

  • ‚Ä¢
    A lower threshold catches more spam but increases false positives, raising the cost of missed real emails
  • ‚Ä¢
    A higher threshold reduces false positives but lets more spam through, increasing wasted time and security risks

help.heading: Calculating the total cost
help.body:
• ‚Ä¢
    Enter the cost of missing real email and cost of missing spam email in the respective input boxes
  • ‚Ä¢
    Adjust the threshold value using a slider
  • ‚Ä¢
    Total cost is displayed above the graph along with the number of real emails missed and number of spam emails missed

S11.S11_D1_F59_C1: Here is our Cost Calculator! If we miss the real email it will cost us $20 because it could be a real customer email. This could lead to lost business, delayed responses, or unhappy clients.
S11.S11_D2_F60_C2: Oh, that's too much! If we miss too many real emails then it will cost us a lot!
S11.S11_D3_F60_C1: Yes. If we miss a spam email then also it costs us $2. It's a smaller cost, but still important because we waste time dealing with emails that should have been filtered out. We end up reading, deleting, or sorting unnecessary messages
S11.S11_D4_F61_C2: Got it! So missing real emails is more costly because it affects our business, while missing spam costs us time.
S11.S11_D3_F61_C1: Exactly, now set the threshold to 75% using a slider.
S11.S11_D4_F62_C2: At this threshold, we will miss 48 real emails and move them into spam, and we will miss 60 spam emails and mark them as real emails.
S11.S11_D5_F63_C1: What is the total cost if the cost of missing a real email is $20 and the cost of missing a spam email is $2?
S11.S11_D6_F64_C2: I see if we increase the threshold the cost is decreasing, so can we increase the threshold to 90%?
S11.S11_D7_F65_C1: No Ethan, if we increase the threshold to 90%, it will definitely reduce the total cost, but we miss more spam emails, wasting even more time.
S11.S11_D8_F66_C2: Oh yes! We need to find a good balance between catching spam and reducing cost.
S11.S11_D9_F67_C1: Now Ethan, can you please set a threshold value in your code and complete the development of this spam filter?

S_12.S12_D1_F70_C1: Great job, Ethan! We've built a spam filter using probability, and it's already making a difference.
S_12.S12_D2_F71_C2: Yeah! Learning how conditional probability, independence, and cost analysis work together really helped fine-tune our threshold.
S_12.S12_D3_F72_C1: Exactly. By balancing false positives and false negatives, we created a smarter system that actually works in a real-world setting.
S_12.S12_D4_F73_C2: And the best part? This isn't just theory, it's a real solution that makes our inbox more efficient every day!

Your insights will help create a smarter, more efficient inbox!

conditional_probability.definition: Conditional Probability is the probability of an event occurring given that another event has already happened.

two_way_table.definition: Two-way Tables are the tables used to organize data into categories and compare two variables.

independence.definition: Independence in probability means two events are independent if one happening does not affect the probability of the other happening.

threshold.definition: Threshold value is a limit or boundary that separates one category from another.

thresholds.definition: Threshold value is a limit or boundary that separates one category from another.

false_positive.definition: False Positive is a result where a test incorrectly identifies the presence of a condition when it is actually absent.

false_positives.definition: False Positive is a result where a test incorrectly identifies the presence of a condition when it is actually absent.

false_negatives.definition: False Negative is a result where a test fails to detect a condition that is actually present.

classification.definition: Classification is the process of categorizing or labeling data based on specific characteristics.

independent.definition: Independent refers to two features where the presence of one feature does not affect the probability of the other feature appearing.

data_analysis.definition: Data Analysis is the process of collecting, organizing, and studying information (data) to find useful patterns or answers.

classification_thresholds.definition: Classification thresholds are values used to decide how to classify the data into different categories.
